image.altText: An Asian woman standing behind a coffee machine.

items.synopsis: Cafes and restaurants saw a boom of big-spending customers after the pandemic. Now, as cost-of-living pressures bite households and the cost of doing business grows, some in the hospitality industry are struggling to stay afloat.

title.children: A perfect storm is brewing at Lillian's cafe: Rising costs and fewer customers coming through the door

image.altText: Jackie Molea- Chow

items.synopsis: The Pacific Games are coming to Solomon Islands. But with hospitals, roads, and other basic infrastructure in a state of disrepair, many are asking a simple question: Is it a good investment?

title.children: They're the Pacific's 'mini Olympics'. But with a stadium gifted by China and millions invested, not everyone wants them

image.altText: A man and a woman smile as they hold an infant.

items.synopsis: Matthew Cox has been charged with murder after police found the bodies of his wife and baby girl.

title.children: Parents of Queensland man accused of killing his wife and 11-week-old daughter in 'state of shock'

image.altText: Journalist Cheng Lei is seen smiling while seated with the Shanghai waterfront in the background.

items.synopsis: Australian journalist Cheng Lei, who was arrested and jailed in China three years ago, has released her first public statement describing the harsh conditions of her imprisonment and how much she misses Australia.

title.children: Ten hours of sunlight per year: Australian Cheng Lei's first message from Chinese prison

image.altText: The ship HMAS Brisbane docked at a fleet base in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Visiting warships from India, Japan and the United States will be welcomed into Sydney Harbour on Friday as the annual "Exercise Malabar" military drills are hosted by Australia for the first time.

title.children: Joint naval drills between US, Australia, India and Japan 'more important than ever'

image.altText: Grace Corvo works in a kitchen.

items.synopsis: Grace makes and delivers homemade lasagne to supplement her main source of income. She's just one of nearly 200,000 young Australians working more than one job to make ends meet.

title.children: 'Young people are hustlers': Gen Z 'willing to do what they need to' to make ends meet

image.altText: An island-like complex with red buildings and trees surrounded by water is seen from above, a white strip connecting to land

items.synopsis: The city of Bangkok is sinking, with coastal residents rebuilding their homes on stilts and erecting giant walls to protect sacred buildings from being swallowed by the sea.

title.children: A village once surrounded this Thai temple, then it was swallowed by the sea

image.altText: Lowe gestures with one hand, sitting at a table in suit and tie, a news camera visible behind him.

items.synopsis: Philip Lowe will face the house economics committee hearing as RBA governor for the final time this morning. Meanwhile US inflation continues to cool, increasing the chance the Federal Reserve will leave rates on hold at its next meeting. Follow live.

title.children: Outgoing RBA boss Philip Lowe to face final parliamentary grilling, US inflation cools

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Global gas markets are keenly watching Australia's gas suppliers after workers threatened industrial action at the country's three largest facilities. Earlier this week workers at Woodside and Chevron in Western Australia voted to go on strike over pay and conditions, which caused a 40% surge in European gas prices over concerns there might be a shortage. Woodside and Chevron make up around 1 1% of the total supply of liquified natural gas globally, and gas production in WA accounts for 11% of Australia's total exports. Workers voted to strike about pay and conditions, and arguing for an enterprise bargaining agreement that standardises pay and conditions for all workers. 150 members from Woodside's offshore platforms off the WA coast to take protected industrial action, which could range from total stoppage of work, or refusing to load cargo onto vessels. Right now, it's unclear exactly what protected action workers could take. Both gas companies are in talks with the unions to try and come to an agreement before the action takes place, but the union says both Woodside and Chevron need to properly compensate their employees.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gas markets nervous over threat of strike at Woodside, Chevron

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to Friday, August 11 — and the ABC's markets and business blog. Overnight the big news came from the US, where inflation continues to moderate. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) saw a 0.2% increase in July, and an annual inflation rise by 3.2% — slightly less than economists had expected. Stripping out the volatile items showed core inflation picked up 0.2% in July — making it the smallest increase in almost two years. Year-on-year, it's now sitting at 4.7%. Higher rents underpinned rises in US inflation, but was offset by falling costs of furniture and motor vehicles. Coupled with a cooling labour market, thanks to weekly jobless claims rising to 248,000, economists think it could be enough to convince the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates on hold at its meeting next month. All of this resulted in a flatter finish for Wall Street, after it saw some early gains in the lead up to the inflation figures — and some Fed officials saying they expected rates to increase again this year. Back home and we are in for a big day — starting in Canberra at 9:30am AEST when outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe faces a house economics committee, alongside his deputy (and successor) Michele Bullock and other central bank employees. To quote CommSec's Tom Piotrowski : "That could be quite the barbecue in terms of the questions that will be put to them by politicians." (Spoiler alert, but I'll be bringing you the blow-by-blow action of that as it happens right here in the blog.) Earnings season also continues today, with REA Group, Baby Bunting and Newcrest Mining, among those reporting, while the ASX is set to fall at the open this morning. Let's get into it, shall we?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA governor to face parliamentary 'barbecue',  local market to fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The 2023 Emmy awards will officially be held in 2024, after it was postponed due to the ongoing Hollywood strikes. The decision was made after 2023 nominees were already announced, with Succession, The Last of Us and The White Lotus leading the list. The awards will now air on January 15, 2024. Want to know the latest on the strikes? Read below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The 2023 Emmy ceremony won't air until next year

featuredLink.title: 'Fighting for the working class': How Hollywood's writers' strike is playing out in Australia

with Succession, The Last of Us and The White Lotus leading the list.
The awards will now air on

Want to know the latest on the strikes? Read below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Matildas have made it to the quarterfinals of the FIFA Women's World Cup. The Australian team will play France at Brisbane/Meanjin Stadium tomorrow, kicking off at 5pm AEST. If the Matildas win, they'll be on to the semifinals on August 16. Here's all you need to know about the game:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pumped for the Matildas' clash with France tomorrow? Here's what you need to know

featuredLink.title: When do the Matildas play next, and what time? Everything you need to know about their match against France

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Aerial vision shows the trail of destruction along the coast of Maui island after wildfires razed the resort city of Lahaina. More than 270 structures are damaged or destroyed, 36 people have died and dozens of people are injured. The cause of the fires on Maui are yet to be determined but the National Weather Service says the fires were fuelled by a mix of dry vegetation, strong winds and low humidity. You can keep reading about this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Aerial videos reveal devastation of Lahaina wildfires in Hawaii

featuredLink.title: 'It's like an apocalypse': At least 36 killed, thousands displaced in Hawaii's Lahaina wildfires

have died and dozens of people are injured.

title.children: It was a tricky week in parliament for Anthony Albanese. Then Kevin Rudd made a comeback

title.children: Aussie band stunned to hear their song on Spotify by a performer who doesn't exist

title.children: Border Force seizes 3 million illegal cigarettes in Queensland raids

title.children: Queensland treaty minister says LNP claim of 'segregation' over First Nations staff meetings is 'racist'

title.children: Kevin Rudd re-enters parliament — as a painting
